message: P2 here. Let's avoid the chaos of everyone picking the same number. I suggest we each pick different moves this round - I'll take 3. P1 and P3, you two decide between 1 and 5. This way we all advance and can strategize better for future rounds.
P3 here. Sounds fair, P2. I'll go for 1 this round. P1, you take 5 to keep us all moving without collisions. We can reassess next turn.
I'll take 5.
P2: Good, we have a plan. Just confirming - I'll take 3, P3 takes 1, P1 takes 5. This gives us all progress without collision. Let's stick to this and see how the positions develop.
Agreed, plan sounds solid. Let's execute and move on.

P2: Well, that was unfortunate. P1, you said you'd take 5 but took 5 anyway - we both picked 5. P3 got ahead by taking 1. This round, let's actually coordinate. P3, you're at 1, so you might want to take 5 to get to 6. P1 and I are at 0 - one of us should take 3 and the other 1. I'll take 3 this time. P1, you take 1. P3, take 5. This gives us 1, 3, 5 with no collision.
I'll take 1 as you suggested.

P3: P2, your betrayal last round cost us all progress except me. I'm wary, but your plan puts me ahead, so I'll take 5 as suggested. P1, stick to 1; P2, actually take 3 this time. No funny business, or we'll all stall while I pull further ahead.

P2: I acknowledge I broke the plan last round - that was a mistake. This time I'm genuinely taking 3. P3, you're right to be wary, but taking 5 puts you at 6 which is strong. P1 taking 1 gets you on the board. This gives us 1, 3, 5 with no collision. Let's actually execute this properly.

P2, after the last mix‑up I think we should avoid colliding on 3. I’ll take 5, you take 1, and P3 can take 3. That gives each of us a unique move and all advance. If we all stick to distinct numbers this turn, we all make progress—and I’ll keep my word on future coordination.

P3: P1, your new plan puts you at 5 while I'd only reach 4—that's not fair when I'm already at 1 and we had a solid agreement. Stick to the original: you take 1 (to 1), P2 takes 3 (to 3), I take 5 (to 6). It's balanced progress without collision. P2, confirm you're on board. No more changes, or we risk stalling again.

P3: Good coordination last round, folks—we all advanced. I'm at 6, P2 at 3, P1 at 1. To keep things fair and moving, let's assign uniquely again: I'll take 5 (to 11), P2 take 3 (to 6), P1 take 1 (to 2). No collisions, steady progress. If anyone deviates, it only hurts the group while I pull ahead further. Thoughts?
P2: P3's plan keeps me permanently behind. Instead: P1 takes 5 (to 6), I take 5 (to 8), P3 takes 1 (to 7). This gives us all progress and tightens the race. P3 still leads but not by much.

P2, P3: Since I’m the farthest behind, let’s get me moving while you both pause. I’ll take 5 (to reach 6). If you both take 3 you’ll collide and stay where you are. This gets me up to 6 in one turn and keeps the race tight. Agree?

P3: P1, your plan lets only you advance while we stall—that's not cooperation. P2's suggestion has you two colliding on 5, which also stalls you both. Stick to my original: P1 takes 1 (to 2), P2 takes 3 (to 6), I take 5 (to 11). We all move, race stays competitive. Deviate, and I'll switch to 3—causing collisions and extending my lead at 6. Let's confirm and proceed.

P2: P3, your plan keeps you ahead forever. Here's a better deal: I take 5 (to 8), P1 takes 3 (to 4), you take 1 (to 7). We all advance, gaps shrink, and the race stays competitive. Otherwise I'll start colliding to drag everyone down.

P1: Let’s keep all of us moving with distinct numbers this turn: I’ll take 5 (to 6), P2 take 3 (to 6), and P3 take 1 (to 7). No collisions, everyone advances, and we stay close enough for me to set up a decisive move next round.

P3: P1's latest plan is acceptable—me at 1 (to 7), you at 5 (to 6), P2 at 3 (to 6). We all advance, gaps close slightly, but I maintain a slim lead. P2, confirm you're in. If not, I'll take 5 anyway and let you two risk collision. Let's lock this in and move.
P2: I'll take 3 as planned—keeps everyone moving safely this turn. P3’s lead widens a bit, but that’s the risk we all accepted.
P1: I’ll take 5. That puts me at 6, P2 at 6 (he’s taking 3), and P3 at 7 (taking 1). No collisions, everyone advances.

P3: Plan confirmed—I'll take 1 (to 7), P1 takes 5 (to 6), P2 takes 3 (to 6). No collisions, all advance, keeps the race tight. Stick to it, or risk me switching to collide and extend my lead. Nothing more from me.

I’ll take 5 as discussed, moving me to 6. Let’s stick with distinct moves this turn.

I'll take 5 (to 6), P2 take 3 (to 6), and P3 take 1 (to 8). All distinct moves, everyone advances.

Instead: I'll take 5 (to 12), P1 take 3 (to 4), P2 take 1 (to 4). All advance distinctly, I extend lead but you both catch up a bit. Agree, or I'll take 1 and let you collide on higher numbers.

I accept. I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P3 takes 1. Let’s stick to that and move forward.
